key_channel_insights.line_content: OTA availability fell sharply, with 13 % of website itineraries now missing and parity sliding to 83 %, exposing long-haul routes to 19 % average mark-ups when OTAs are higher.
MSE still prices below the website on 74 % of itineraries, yet the share is down almost 10 ppts MoM and parity has risen to 14 %, indicating recent control efforts are gaining traction.
GDS continues to show higher fares on 73 % of ODs—especially outside Spain—though the average uplift remains modest at +0.34 %, pointing to a competitiveness rather than revenue-loss challenge.

conclusion.line_content: This report provides a high-level summary of the price discrepancies observed across different channels.  It is important to note that the data contains many nuances depending on various factors such as market conditions, booking windows, and the competitive landscape. Understanding these subtleties can be critical in optimizing pricing strategies and ensuring competitive positioning.

As part of our 'PriceEye' solution, we are developing an intuitive dashboard designed to help your airline's analysts drill down into this data. This tool will allow you to uncover and focus on critical actionable insights, enabling your team to make data-driven decisions with confidence.

We are here to support you in leveraging these insights to enhance your revenue management and distribution strategies. Please don't hesitate to connect with our team for more information about how PriceEye can assist you in achieving your business objectives.

ota_highlights.line_content: 13 % of website itineraries had no matching OTA offer last week—up 2.9 ppts WoW and more than double MoM.
Price parity now covers 83 % of itineraries but has slipped 2.5 ppts WoW and 6.8 ppts MoM.
When OTAs are higher, the average mark-up jumps to 19 % on long-haul versus 7 % on short-haul.

ota_summary_high_level_comparison.line_content: Availability gaps rose 28 % WoW, confirming coverage as the key disparity driver.
Parity still rules at 83 % but is eroding; close monitoring is required to prevent further slippage.
Incidence of OTA-lower fares is minimal and stable, averaging a 6–7 % discount.
Uplifts are infrequent yet material on long-haul, averaging +8 % overall.

ota_summary_by_region.line_content: 13.3 % OTA unavailability; OTA higher in 2.4 % of ODs with a 7 % premium.
Unavailability at 12.8 % (+3.4 ppts WoW); OTA higher cases carry a 19 % premium.

ota_summary_by_point_of_origin.line_content: Higher OTA gaps (13.9 %) and slightly lower parity (82.8 %); OTA premiums average 8 % when higher.
Better availability (10.6 %) but a higher share of OTA mark-ups (2.8 %) averaging 9–10 %.

ota_summary_by_booking_window.line_content: Availability weakest at 17.7 % OTA N/A; parity dips to 79.3 %.
OTA gaps low at 4.2 % yet tripled WoW; OTA higher fares appear in 3.1 % with a 9 % premium.

mse_highlights.line_content: Same-price share climbed to 14 %, up 2.7 ppts WoW and 3.9 ppts MoM.
Nearly 79 % of short-haul ODs are cheaper on MSE, though incidence is falling 10 ppts MoM.
Average under-cut remains shallow at 5–6 %, making frequency—not depth—the main leakage factor.

mse_summary_high_level_comparison.line_content: Coverage gap widened 1.3 ppts WoW to 11.3 %.
MSE undercuts dropped 3.6 ppts WoW and almost 10 ppts MoM, signalling better control.
Parity now at 14.4 %, a positive momentum that should continue to be nurtured.
Over-pricing negligible, posing no strategic threat.

mse_summary_by_region.line_content: Undercutting still high (78.7 %) but down 10 ppts MoM; discounts average 5–6 %.
Parity dominates (62.8 %); under-cuts limited to 26.1 % with deeper ~7 % gaps.

mse_summary_by_point_of_origin.line_content: MSE cheaper on 76 % of itineraries, but incidence is falling steadily (-4 ppts WoW).
Lower-fare share shrinks to 67 %; however, discount depth edges higher (-6–8 %).

mse_summary_by_booking_window.line_content: Lower MSE pricing on 70 % of ODs, down 11.9 ppts MoM—strong recent progress.
Undercutting peaks at 83 %; sustained focus here is essential to protect early-booking revenue.

gds_highlights.line_content: 73 % of itineraries price higher in GDS, albeit with a modest +0.34 % uplift.
GDS higher pricing reaches 83 % abroad, 13 ppts above Spain.
Far-out bookings show widest premium (+0.47 %) and 77 % over-pricing frequency.

gds_summary_high_level_comparison.line_content: Availability leakage rose to 12.6 %, up 5.5 ppts MoM.
Over-pricing remains dominant, though incidence eased 0.8 ppts WoW.
Undercuts modest and shallow (-0.12 %), presenting low revenue risk.
Exact matches are virtually absent at 0.04 %.

gds_summary_by_region.line_content: GDS higher in 72 % of ODs with +0.35 % premium; 12 % fares missing.
Over-pricing peaks at 78 %; fare absence rises to 22 %, the channel’s weakest area.

gds_summary_by_point_of_origin.line_content: GDS higher on 70 % of ODs (+0.34 %); undercutting appears on 18 %.
GDS higher climbs to 83 %; fare absence at 16 % signals need for stricter control.

gds_summary_by_booking_window.line_content: 71 % of itineraries GDS higher (+0.27 %); availability gaps persist at 16 %.
Premium widens to +0.47 % and over-pricing frequency to 77 %, despite lower fare absence.
